The gravitational force of the moon creates a net downward force perpendicular to the direction of the moon from the earth, so it's on either side of the earth (roughly around the poles, often). This pushes the water down and causes the bulge on both sides of the earth (actually, all around it). The earth rotates through the region of the bulge, causing the tides.

Imagine thinking of the Earth in three sections.  The near side to the moon, the middle, and the far side to the moon.  The gravity in that order is strongest, weaker, weakest.  The stronger gravity pulls the near side the most.  The weaker gravity pulls the middle a little less, and the weakest gravity pulls the weakest on the far side of the Earth.  In other words, the far side of the Earth gets 'left behind' a little bit, so it also bulges on the far side.

Well, not exactly.  We always see the same side of the moon.  The myth is that the dark side stays dark -- it doesn't.  In fact during a solar eclipse, it's high noon on the "dark side."
It does, just not as much as the earth does.  The closer you are, the more you get pulled -- the earth is closer to the moon than the oceans on the far side.

Everything gets pulled: water on the near side, the earth itself, and water on the far side.

The water on the near side gets pulled more than the earth, so it bulges.  No problem.  Then the EARTH gets pulled AWAY from the water on the far side.  So the far side water bunches up too, because it can't keep up with the Earth getting pulled out from underneath it.  It's just like an earthquake where the ocean floor drops, creating a giant bulge (tidal wave) -- only slower.

Hope that helps.

The Earth is basically orbiting around the Moon. The Earth and the Moon have an equal gravitational effect on each other (see Newton's 3rd law). The force from the Earth-Moon gravitational attraction is divided into much more mass for Earth, meaning less acceleration and a smaller orbit. The first tide (near the moon) is in a closer orbit and the second in a farther orbit, but their orbiting at the same speed, the effect it that the closer one want to fall closer and the farther escape farther.

Also, on average, the water of the Earth is NOT being pulled towards the Moon, on average, everything on Earth is equal in being pulled towards the Moon, so it's not that water is being pulled more while the Earth is relatively sitting still. Instead, some water is being pulled more than the average pull on Earth and some is being pulled less than the average pull on Earth, which creates the 2 high tides.

It's not being pulled in the opposite direction, it's being pulled less there because it's farther away. The overall effect is that there's less force toward the center of the Earth on the same and opposite sides, which make the direction of force on the surface of the Earth point just slightly towards those areas. The water wants to have a surface along a plane perpendicular to those forces, which make the water surface incline towards the high-tide areas.

It's centrifugal force. The Earth and the Moon are rotating around each other, and the seas on the far side of the Earth are being flung outwards due to the rotation. The seas on the far side farthest from the Moon experience less of the Moon's gravity, so they get flung farther outwards than the seas at the sides that are nearer to the Moon.

@kdum8, when the moon is overhead, it's pulling the water away from the Earth.  
When the moon is directly below, it's pulling the Earth away from the water.

In the latter case, the Earth's center-of-gravity is closer to the moon than the ocean.

So if you stop the video at 20 seconds... 
The ocean on the left is pulled toward the left the most (big arrow)
The Earth is pulled toward the left somewhat less (middle arrow)
The oceans on the right are pulled left-ward the least (small arrow)

Are you claiming that the moon PULLS THE EARTH AWAY FROM ITS WATER? That is very hard to believe! That would imply that the Earth is being pulled around by the Moon! This makes more sense: the Earth-Moon system rotates around its center of mass, which is somewhere between their individual centers of mass (closer to Earth). In other words, the Earth and Moon both orbit this collective center of mass. Therefore, it is centrifugal force that causes the high tide on the side opposite the moon.
@makro80 it makes one rotation per month. it is 'tidally locked' to us, the same way mercury is tidally locked to the sun- mercury has a 'year' that is one long day.

@makro80 It is rotating but at specific rate that allows one face to always point towards the Earth. This may be hard to visualize in your mind so a handy trick is to use two common objects. A dinner plate can be the earth and a coffee mug can be the moon. Imagine the handle side is the side we can see. The mug has to revolve around the plate AND rotate as it revolves in order to always show the plate the handle side. *notice what happens if you stop rotation and don't twist your wrist.

WRONG!  The first google result you find does not qualify as a valid source for this kind of information.  The high tide on the far side of the moon is caused by the "centrifugal force" acting away from the moon, due to the Earth rotating around the Earth-moon center of gravity.  The moon's gravity does not "stretch out" or "elongate" the oceans - it only causes the heaping of the oceans on the near side.  The Earth's motion, indirectly a result of the Moon, accounts for the far side high tide.

(cont from second comment) and finally, the moon WAS once very close to earth, and generated massive tides, dragging and breaking rocks into the fresh water releasing minerals to begin life, but thats another story. as the earth moves through the bulges, it tries to drag them with it via friction. the gravity of the now "ahead" bulges, then pulls the moon with it, hence, the earth gives the moon energy,and flings it further away from us in accordance to their diminishing gravitational attraction

(cont from first comment) secondly, as the moon orbits once every 27 days in the same direction as earth rotates, so to do the two bulges (relative to space). as earth rotates once every 24 hours, it rotates within these bulges, catching and surpassing them to give the tidal effect. with every new day the moon is now 1/27 of 360 degrees ahead, therefore, it will take 1/27 of 24 hours i.e. around 53 minutes to catch the bulge again, therefore, high/low tides come around 53 mins later each day.

@NintendoRick The moon is rotating around it's axis AND it is orbiting the earth. It is considered "tidally locked" to the Earth because its rotation and orbit are synced up in a way that makes it always show the same side to the Earth. As it moves in its orbit it spins just the right amount to show the same side. The side we see is called the "near side of the moon". There is also a "far side of the moon" which looks quite a bit different (look it up on wikipedia).

@backhandable An object with more mass has more gravity than an object with less mass. Additionally, gravity dissipates quickly over distance. If you double the distance between two objects, the gravity is reduced to 1/4th of its original strength. The Earth has much more mass than the moon, and we are much closer to the Earth. Due to these factors, the gravity we feel from the Earth is significantly greater than the gravity we feel from the moon, so much so that it isn't even noticeable.
